usageNotes: The practice of making products usable by people with disabilities. Always prioritize accessibility in design and development. Use inclusive language and follow WCAG guidelines.
The overall experience a person has when interacting with a product or service. Abbreviate as UX when space is limited. Focus on user needs and pain points.
Deceptive UX practices that trick users into unintended actions. Never implement dark patterns. Instead, use transparent and honest design practices that respect user autonomy.
Design approach that ensures interfaces work well across different screen sizes and devices. Always implement responsive design principles. Test on multiple devices and screen sizes.
Low-fidelity structural blueprint of a page or screen. Use wireframes in early design phases to focus on layout and functionality before visual design. Keep them simple and avoid detailed styling.

Design implementation that matches the original design exactly down to the pixel level. While attention to detail is important, prioritize user experience and accessibility over pixel-perfect accuracy. Consider responsive behavior and different screen densities.

Design and development approach that starts with mobile devices and progressively enhances for larger screens. Prioritize mobile experience given the majority of users access content via mobile devices.
Content visible without scrolling on a webpage. This term originates from print newspapers. Use sparingly as screen sizes vary greatly. Focus on progressive disclosure and content hierarchy instead.

Percentage of users who complete a desired action (purchase, signup, etc.). Use to measure the effectiveness of design and content changes. Always define what constitutes a conversion for your specific context.

Any person or group with an interest in or influence over a project's outcome. Include stakeholders in design decisions and keep them informed of progress. Identify primary and secondary stakeholders early in projects.
